description: From Medieval Latin dīvergō (“bend away from, go in a different direction”), from Latin dī- + vergō (“bend”).

verbs.description: diverge (third-person singular simple present diverges, present participle diverging, simple past and past participle diverged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, literally, of lines or paths) To run apart; to separate; to tend into different directions.
examples: Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, / And sorry I could not travel both /  […]

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively, of interests, opinions, or anything else) To become different; to run apart; to separate; to tend into different directions.
examples: The brooding, black-clad singer bridged a stark divide that emerged in the recording industry in the 1950s, as post-Elvis pop singers diverged into two camps and audiences aligned themselves with either the sideburned rebels of rock 'n' roll or the cowboy-hatted twangsters of country music.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, literally, of a line or path) To separate, to tend into a different direction (from another line or path).
examples: The sidewalk runs next to the street for a few miles, then diverges from it and turns north.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively, of an interest, opinion, or anything else) To become different, to separate (from another line or path).
examples: The software is pretty good, except for a few cases where its behavior diverges from user expectations.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, mathematics, of a sequence, series, or function) Not to converge: to have no limit, or no finite limit.
examples:
The sequence 
  
    
      
        
          x
          
            n
          
        
        =
        
          n
          
            2
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle x_{n}=n^{2}}
  
 diverges to infinity: that is, it increases without bound.
